signature: NHS Forth Valley
body:
Dear lynxjj56  
I'm sorry to hear that you were disappointed by the advice given.  
Dental practices are working under restrictions as set out in the current infection and prevention control guidance due to the ongoing Covid-19 situation. This is affecting patient throughput in dental practices and due to this they are having to prioritise their own registered patients. Until Scottish Government feel it is safe to ease these restrictions there is likely to be very little change and the practices will still need to work through a backlog of care.  
Unlike medical practice registration patients do not have to be registered with a dental practice in their own Health Board. At this current time very, few dental practices in Scotland are taking on new patients, registration is challenging. At the Dental Helpline we are advising any registered patients to remain registered with practices where the distance is deemed reasonable as it is their best chance at accessing regular dental care.  
A registered practice will be able to deliver any potential follow up care as well as emergency care. The dental service delivered through the helpline is for emergency care only and patients are required to travel to appointments in clinics which are spread across Forth Valley. Your own registered dentist will know your mouth and needs best as they can access your clinical dental notes, these do not follow you like medical notes.  
With all this in mind we are advising patients to stay registered where they can in the shorter term as it is in their best interests to do so. Meanwhile, Scottish Government and the Health Board are working to look at what they can do to improve access to care.  
Lesley Yeaman  
Clinical Director, Public Dental Service  
NHS Forth Valley

We have recently moved to a new telephone system which we hope will help us to meet the very high patient demand that we and all Practices are currently experiencing.  We appreciate how frustrating it is to have to wait on the phone line.  We have set up more staff to answer the phones and we also now have a call back option so that if you do not wish to wait on the phone you can ask that we call you back when you get to the front of the incoming call queue.  Patients have feedback to us that they are finding this facility helpful.
Regarding the difficulties picking up your prescription.  The pick up point for prescriptions and medication is currently the window at the side of the building.  I am sorry that you were not admitted inside the building when you came to discuss your husband's prescription. The Dispensary counter inside the building is currently not being used and all dealings with the Dispensary are via the side window.  
I am sorry that you were given the impression that we are not allowing patients to walk into the surgery.  We adopted a closed door to keep staff and patients safe during the peak of the pandemic with a buzzer entry system but we have not used this for some time now and the front door has been open to all patients to walk in.  We did re-instigate the buzzer system for a very short period in December when the Omicron variant was at its peak so I think that this may have been when you visited. 
If you would like to discuss anything from your feedback I would be happy to talk to you and we value your comments and ideas for any improvements.

Best wishes
Jackie Evans
Practice Manager

signature: Isabel Saunders, Assistant Psychological Wellbeing Practitioner, Inclusion Thurrock IAPT, Inclusion Thurrock IAPT
body:
Dear ariess21,  
Thank you for your feedback on our service.  
Sorry to read that you felt in a constant low mood and you were not able to go out without feeling sick or overthinking that something bad was going to happen. It must be so hard as well, to feel that people were looking or judging you when you were out, or been fidgety and feeling hot when you were close to other people, mainly strangers, in a crowd, or presenting in front of other people. It is understandable that your symptoms peaked after lockdown, as you were back to work, college and social events!  
I am so glad that you took the courage to self-refer to Inclusion Thurrock, and thank you for sharing your experience of working with a trainee; trainees are allocated to a client, when they have the knowledge and confidence to understand the difficulties that clients can bring in to the sessions, supporting with offering tools and techniques.  
It seems you had a great report with your therapist; I am very happy as well to read that you felt listened to, supported and guided, that you were able to trust on your therapist and talk openly about how you were feeling, you had the commitment to work on the homework and to put yourself on that "uncomfortable situations" to work on your social anxiety, and as a consequence, you were able to understand your emotions and behaviours, to set your goals, and even you were willing to add challenges you wanted to achieve before your next session!  
Wow! You worked so hard ariess21, I am not surprised you got these fantastic results from your treatment, well done! You must be so proud of your journey, now feeling happier, healthier and more confident to cope with any situation that can make you feel nervous or worried.. if it ever happens again.  
Continue with that great enthusiasm, all the best in the future.  
J. Isabel Saunders

signature: Isabel Saunders, Assistant Psychological Wellbeing Practitioner, Inclusion Thurrock IAPT, Inclusion Thurrock IAPT
body:
Dear StevieC,  
Thank you for sharing your experience with Inclusion Thurrock.  
I'm glad you took the advice of reaching for help, contacted your GP for medication, and after feeling something else needed to be done, you self-refer to our service. I am sure it was not easy to hold a lot of anxiety, worry and baggage, as you described it; and that lockdown didn't make it easier for you. Of course, you should feel proud of yourself for taking that step forward!  
I can see you had a good rapport with Claire, feeling empathy, kindness and honesty; you trusted on her and being honest allowed you to get more from your sessions, as you highlighted feeling free and like you were receiving a gift.  
You put the hard work into learning the techniques, even when sometimes you felt it daunting, you stayed and worked to get your life back on track.  
You are right, breaking in bite size pieces permitted you to understand your emotions and behaviours in that specific situations in your life and obtain more understanding of yourself.  
I am sure Claire is very proud of the work you achieved during your sessions and appreciated your openness and motivation, which in return allowed the client/therapist relationship to evolve.  
Well done StevieC, continue with the hard work, wish you the best in the future.  
J. Isabel Saunders

In the past few months the number of calls we have been receiving has increased, resulting in all our lines becoming busy (previously we always had some capacity). We became aware that, dependant on the network you are calling from,  patients are either being informed they have dialled a wrong number or the number is unobtainable. Unfortunately there was no quick fix to this, so the decision we have reached is to replace our telephone system in its entirety with effect from 16th February 2022.

In the meantime please do continue to try as our lines are working.

I trust the forgoing answers your query and thanks again for contacting us.

Kind regards
Paul Butterworth
Practice Manager

signature: Murdina MacDonald, Lead Cancer Nurse, Cancer Services, NHS Fife
body:
Dear VHK  
Thank you for taking time to share with us your thoughts and expeience of our service. We recognise being told you or a loved one may have cancer can be overwhelming.It is reassuring to know that at this time of concern an alarm for you and your mum that Lorna was able to provide you with detailed information and support.  
The role of our patient navigator includes helping to facilitate the patient’s journey and we know this journey can take many different pathwaysand our patient navigator will provide specific and poignant information and provide the best options.  
Person Centred care is important to us and one element of Katie's role is to provide timely feedback on the findings from the scan as we recognise waiting for results can be a frightening time.  
We know it's comforting for the patient and their family in talking to their health care team and are pleased that this role provided by both Lorna and Katie has been reassuring for you and your mum. We are pleased that you are feeling supported as Katie is helping guideyou and your mum through the often-complicated health care system.  
I am so pleased that the varied means and methods of communication between you and your mum and our team has contibuted to building a trusting relationship, helped share information with each other without having to travel from your own home which is an ordeal for your elderly mum.  
Can I please take this opportunity on behalf of the team to wish your mum well in her appointment on Thursday.  
Thank you for your gracious comments which I will share with our team. Katie and Lorna will be delighted to know they met you, your mum's and the wider familys concerns.  
Best Wishes  
Murdina

signature: Priory Medical Centre
body:
Dear Anonymous

Thank you for your feedback. 

I am sorry you are dissatisfied with the service here at Priory Medical Centre. 
Since the pandemic the phone lines have experienced an unprecedented increase in calls and our receptionists work hard to answer and deal with all our patients, with the resources available to them. Since the pandemic our reception team has had to deal with immense pressure, along with daily complaints and anger from patients for simply carrying out the role that has been asked of them. 
I would like to state that myself and the Partners at the practice have implemented the current way of working, following advice and guidelines from NHS England and support the receptionists in what is becoming an increasingly difficult role. 
Currently our reception team can only make urgent and routine telephone consultations with a GP. The GP will then decide if a patient needs to be seen at a face-to-face appointment. The practice also offers an online e-consult system for appointments of a nonurgent nature, to reduce pressure on the telephone system. 
As always it is patient choice where they register with a GP, and we are sorry you feel you need to register elsewhere. However, the practice has endeavoured to remain as accessible to patients as possible during these tough times.


Yours Sincerely 

Ms B Purves
Practice Manager

signature: Blue Dykes Surgery
body:
Dear Patient

Thank you so much for your comment, we really value patient feedback. 

We're sorry to hear that your experience has caused you some upset. When our clinicians file away blood test results a task is sent to our reception team to book any necessary follow up appointments. These tasks are either "urgent" where we try to contact the patient within 2 days or "routine" where we will try to contact the patient within 2 weeks. Without further investigation we would be unable to tell you if your blood test results were marked as urgent or routine. We usually try to contact patients by telephone call in the first instance however if we are unable to contact we will send an SMS or a letter.

We know that it can be a very unsettling time for patients to wait for the next available appointment to discuss their blood test results and for this we apologise. We would like to reassure you that any blood test results that require immediate attention are dealt with on the same day by our clinical team.

Kind Regards

Royal Primary Care

signature: Stroke Association
body:
Comment from the Stroke Association  
Hello.  
We’re sorry to hear about your mother’s stroke and the concerns you’ve raised.  
Here at the Stroke Association, we’re here for anyone who’s been affected by stroke. You might want to know more about stroke and its effects, be looking for practical information and support, or need someone to talk to. That’s where we can help. If you’d like to talk to us, the Stroke Helpline is open:  
Monday, Thursday and Friday from 9.00am to 5.00pm  
Tuesday and Wednesday from 8.00am to 6.00pm  
Saturday from 10.00am to 1.00pm  
The helpline number is 0303 30 33 100. You can also email us at helpline@stroke.org.uk.  
We also have a range of services across the UK, providing information, advice and support to stroke survivors and their families. You can find out if there’s a service in your area from our website www.stroke.org.uk/finding-support  
Finally, you can find lots of information about stroke on our website at www.stroke.org.uk.  
I hope this is helpful and that your mother is now getting the support that she needs to make the best recovery possible.  
Stroke Helpline  
Stroke Association staff are not medically trained and the information provided does not replace information given to you by your own healthcare provider.  
[SM1]Please make sure you add this at the top of your response

signature: Nicole McInally, Patient Experience and Public Involvement Project Manager, PEPI, NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde
body:
Dear Gordon E1234  
Thank you for getting in touch via Care Opinion.  
I am so sorry that it took so long for your call to be returned by the Out of Hours Service. As you have mentioned COVID has impacted on our services, and the service is experiencing significant pressures due to an increased demand. However, this is not the experience that we want for any of our patients. In the meantime, I will share your story with the Out of Hours Service so that they are aware of your experience and will be in touch with an update.  
Kind Regards  
Nicole

signature: John Carson, Chief Nurse, North Sector, NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde
body:
Dear Andrea26,  
I am sorry to hear about the concerns you raise regarding your son’s care while under our care in the Glasgow Royal Infirmary and the apparent delays arranging transfer to the children’s hospital. This sounds like it was a frightening and frustrating time for you both. I am pleased to hear that you felt the care received at the Queen Elizabeth children’s hospital was outstanding and hope your son is recovering. I know my colleagues from the children’s hospital would welcome the opportunity to respond and share your experience through their teams.  
From the perspective of you and your son’s experience at Glasgow Royal Infirmary, in order for us to investigate the issues you have raised regarding your his care with our services and provide you with a fuller response, it would be helpful if you would agree to contact me at the email or number below to give me his name and date of birth.  
Thanks  
John Carson  
Chief Nurse North Sector  
john.carson@ggc.scot.nhs.uk  
0141 451 5165

body:
Your wording would suggest that only a few services do not use this service for communication with patients but in my experience in reality only a very few are in fact to date only the ENT department communicates using this service which is quite ridiculous in the 21st century.  
Not sure why you mentioned clinical letters as I certainly have not. My complaint is not receiving appointment notifications using this method because departments are not connected to the service, so I find your apology is pointless and uncalled for. In fact I find your response patronising as I have never asked for clinical information being sent using this service.

signature: Doncaster Royal Infirmary
body: Hi Daniel Thank you for sharing your experience with us following your visit to the Emergency Department.  I am sorry to read the lack of communication regarding your discharge and I will pass your feedback on to the General Manager for the department who will discuss with our teams.

signature: Richmond Medical Centre
body:
Dear Imran,
Thank you for your feedback. We strive to provide good customer service at all times to all patients, so we are very disappointed to hear of this situation.
Since your review, we have now put in place a new appointment booking system which is working well to provide a better service for our patients. We have also put a more robust training plan in place for our reception team.
We take all feedback, both negative and positive, on board and thank you for your comments.

signature: Fitzwilliam Hospital
body: Thank you for leaving your lovely review following your recent stay with us. Wishing you all the best in your recovery.

signature: Community Health and Eyecare Limited
body:
Hello, 

Thank you for your review. My apologies for the inconvenience this has caused you. Our Referral Management Booking Team is based in Fulwood, Preston; so they, unfortunately, do not know the area as well as its residents. We can provide location details, however, we do not provide a map of the practices. Though it would appear that the employee in question may have used an outdated version of the MECS providers list, and for that, we can only apologise and reassure you that this has been dealt with. I can confirm that the Boots practice is not on the updated provider list. 

Regarding the phone lines, we are experiencing a spike in calls from new and old patients as the queue remains to be above 30 people regardless of how hard our Referral Management Booking Team work to reduce this. Thank you for bringing the problem about the Live Chat Function to our attention, we have transferred this to our IT team and they are working diligently to fix this issue. 

We hope your appointment has gone well otherwise, and we once again profusely apologise for the inconvenience you experienced. 

Best wishes,
Courtney @ CHEC

signature: Dr Ks Upton's Practice
body:
Hello,

I'm not sure why you've not been able to get an answer after 100 attempts, as our colleagues are answering the telephone as soon as possible, and usually within 3 rings. As you can agree, the Tardis Surgery is a small community practice, and from time to time we're also short staffed due to staffing the covid vaccination clinics, which have absorbed resources from the team. Between Christmas and New Year is a notoriously busy time, and we're doing the upmost to assure that we deliver the best patient care. I would be more than happy to discuss this with you in person.

signature: Selborne Road Medical Centre
body: Thank you so much for taking the time to say something positive and give us all a much needed boost.
